page.title: 12ECOLOGY
page.content: The Mendips is an area of hills and steeply cut valleys, where dairy farming predominates. Long ago it was largely forested but it is now a patchwork quilt of fields. Boundarys are marked by hedges, barbed wire fences, and traditional Mendip dry stone walls. Because the Mendip stone is lime, only lime loving plants survive. These plants provide a suitable habitat for many small creatures. During the spring months the Mendip hills produce a carpet of gay and fragrant flowers which brighten up the dull and uninviting hedgerows. Woodland on the Mendips are a pleasure to walk through as in some hot summers the woods stay quite cool, and in winter the coniferous woodlands also provide a warm and sheltered habitat for many woodland creatures.
